data.name: heading
data.body: Electrostatic Potential Energy

data.name: paragraph
data.body: When a charged particle moves in an electric field, the field exerts a force that can perform work on the particle. When a force F acts on a particle moving from point a to point b, the work W(a->b) done by the force is given by:

data.name: expression
data.body: $W_{a\to b} = \int_{a}^{b} F \, ds = \int_{a}^{b} F \cos \theta \, ds$

data.name: paragraph
data.body: where ds is the infinitesimal displacements along the particle's path and Î¸ is the angle between F and ds.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Since the Electric Field is conservative, the work done by force F can always be expressed in terms of potential energy

data.name: expression
data.body: $W-{a\to b} = U_a - U_b =  - ( U_b - U_a ) = - \Delta U$

data.name: paragraph
data.body: We can see whenever work done is positive change is potential energy is negative and vice versa.

data.name: subheading
data.body: Electric Potential energy of two charges

data.name: paragraph
data.body: The Coulomb's force on \( q_0 \) at a distance \( r \) from a fixed charge \( q \) is given by:

data.name: expression
data.body: \[ F_{q_0 q} (r) = \frac{q q_0}{4 \pi \epsilon_0 r^2} \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: If the two charges have same signs, the force is repulsive, and if the two charges have opposite signs, the force is attractive. The force is not constant during the displacement, so we have to integrate to calculate the work \( W_{a \rightarrow b} \) done on \( q_0 \) by this force as \( q_0 \) moves from \( a \) to \( b \).

data.name: expression
data.body: \[W_{a \rightarrow b} = \int_{a}^{b} \mathbf{F} \cdot d\mathbf{r} = \int_{a}^{b} \frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_0 r^2} \cdot q \cdot q_0 \, dr\]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Being a conservative force, this work is path-independent. From the definition of potential energy, we have:

data.name: expression
data.body: \[ U = U_b - U_a = -W_{a \rightarrow b} = \frac{q q_0}{4 \pi \epsilon_0} \left( \frac{1}{r_a} - \frac{1}{r_b} \right) = \frac{q q_0}{4 \pi \epsilon_0} \left( \frac{1}{r_b} - \frac{1}{r_a} \right) \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: We choose the potential energy of the two-charge system to be zero when they have infinite separation. This means \( U_{\infty} = 0 \). The potential energy when the separation is \( r \) is:

data.name: expression
data.body: \[ U_r = U - U_{\infty} = \frac{q q_0}{4 \pi \epsilon_0} \left( \frac{1}{r} - 0 \right) = \frac{q q_0}{4 \pi \epsilon_0 r} \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: or

data.name: expression
data.body: \[ U_{q_0 q}(r) = \frac{q q_0}{4 \pi \epsilon_0 r} \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: This is the expression for the electric potential energy of two point charges kept at a separation r.

data.name: subheading
data.body: Electric Potential energy of a system of charges

data.name: paragraph
data.body: The electric potential energy due to a system of charges is given by

data.name: expression
data.body: $U = k \sum_{i < j} \frac{q_i \cdot q_j}{|\mathbf{r}_i - \mathbf{r}_j|}$

data.name: paragraph
data.body: For example - Electric potential energy of 4 point charges q1, q2, q3, q4 will be given by :

data.name: expression
data.body: $U = k \left( \frac{q_1 \cdot q_2}{|\mathbf{r}_1 - \mathbf{r}_2|} + \frac{q_1 \cdot q_3}{|\mathbf{r}_1 - \mathbf{r}_3|} + \frac{q_1 \cdot q_4}{|\mathbf{r}_1 - \mathbf{r}_4|} + \frac{q_2 \cdot q_3}{|\mathbf{r}_2 - \mathbf{r}_3|} + \frac{q_2 \cdot q_4}{|\mathbf{r}_2 - \mathbf{r}_4|} + \frac{q_3 \cdot q_4}{|\mathbf{r}_3 - \mathbf{r}_4|} \right)$
